caption: Table 1: (Nonlinear IP) Nonlinear deblurring with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01). (Bold: best, under: second best, green: performance increase, red: performance decrease)
description: This table presents the results of applying different methods for nonlinear deblurring on three datasets (CelebA, FFHQ, and LSUN) with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01).  The metrics used to evaluate the performance are LPIPS (lower is better), PSNR (higher is better), and SSIM (higher is better). The table compares the performance of the proposed DMPlug method against several state-of-the-art methods.  The best and second-best results for each metric are highlighted in bold and underlined, respectively.  Differences in performance compared to the best method are indicated in green (improvement) and red (reduction).

caption: Table 1: (Nonlinear IP) Nonlinear deblurring with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01). (Bold: best, under: second best, green: performance increase, red: performance decrease)
description: This table presents the results of nonlinear deblurring experiments using different methods.  The experiment used images from three datasets (CelebA, FFHQ, and LSUN) with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01). The table compares the performance of several state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods, including BKS-styleGAN, BKS-generic, MCG, ILVR, DPS, Resample, and the proposed DMPlug method.  Performance is evaluated using three metrics: LPIPS (Learned Perceptual Image Patch Similarity), PSNR (Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio), and SSIM (Structural Similarity Index).  The best results for each metric and dataset are shown in bold, while the second-best are underlined.  Performance improvements or decreases compared to the best-performing methods are highlighted in green and red respectively.

caption: Table 1: (Nonlinear IP) Nonlinear deblurring with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01). (Bold: best, under: second best, green: performance increase, red: performance decrease)
description: This table presents the quantitative results of different methods on the task of nonlinear deblurring. The results are reported for three datasets: CelebA, FFHQ, and LSUN. Each dataset contains images with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01). The table compares the performance of the proposed method (DMPlug) with several state-of-the-art methods (BKS-styleGAN, BKS-generic, MCG, ILVR, DPS, and ReSample). The performance is evaluated using three metrics: LPIPS, PSNR, and SSIM. The best and second-best results for each metric are highlighted in bold and underlined, respectively. The green and red numbers indicate the performance increase and decrease compared to the best results, respectively.

caption: Table 1: (Nonlinear IP) Nonlinear deblurring with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01). (Bold: best, under: second best, green: performance increase, red: performance decrease)
description: This table presents the results of a nonlinear inverse problem, specifically non-linear deblurring, with additive Gaussian noise at a standard deviation of 0.01.  The results are compared across multiple datasets (CelebA, FFHQ, LSUN) using various metrics including LPIPS, PSNR, and SSIM.  The table highlights the best performing method (in bold), the second best (underlined), improvements over the best (green), and decrements (red). It showcases the performance of the proposed DMPlug method against several state-of-the-art techniques.

caption: Table 1: (Nonlinear IP) Nonlinear deblurring with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01). (Bold: best, under: second best, green: performance increase, red: performance decrease)
description: This table presents the results of nonlinear deblurring experiments with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01) on three datasets: CelebA, FFHQ, and LSUN.  The table compares the performance of DMPlug against several state-of-the-art methods. The metrics used are LPIPS, PSNR, and SSIM. description: This table presents the results of nonlinear deblurring experiments with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01) on three datasets: CelebA, FFHQ, and LSUN.  It compares the performance of the proposed DMPlug method against several state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods, including BKS-styleGAN, BKS-generic, MCG, ILVR, DPS, and ReSample. caption: Table 1: (Nonlinear IP) Nonlinear deblurring with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01). (Bold: best, under: second best, green: performance increase, red: performance decrease)
description: This table presents the results of a nonlinear inverse problem, specifically image deblurring, using different methods. The images were blurred using a Gaussian kernel and then Gaussian noise was added (σ = 0.01). The table compares the performance of DMPlug with other state-of-the-art methods in terms of LPIPS, PSNR, and SSIM metrics across three datasets: CelebA, FFHQ, and LSUN.  The best results are shown in bold, while the second-best is underlined.  Green indicates an improvement over the best competing method, and red denotes a decrease in performance.

caption: Table 1: (Nonlinear IP) Nonlinear deblurring with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01). (Bold: best, under: second best, green: performance increase, red: performance decrease)
description: This table presents the quantitative results of different methods on the task of nonlinear deblurring with additive Gaussian noise having standard deviation of 0.01. The results are evaluated across three datasets: CelebA, FFHQ, and LSUN.  Metrics used for evaluation include LPIPS, PSNR, and SSIM.  The table highlights the best and second-best performing methods for each metric and dataset.  Green indicates a performance improvement compared to the previous method while red indicates a decrease.

caption: Table 1: (Nonlinear IP) Nonlinear deblurring with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01). (Bold: best, under: second best, green: performance increase, red: performance decrease)
description: This table presents the quantitative results of the proposed DMPlug method and several state-of-the-art methods on the task of nonlinear deblurring.  The results are evaluated on three datasets (CelebA, FFHQ, and LSUN) and three metrics (LPIPS, PSNR, and SSIM). The table highlights the superior performance of the DMPlug method, especially in terms of PSNR and SSIM, compared to the existing methods. It also shows improvements and decrements compared to the best performing methods in different datasets. This demonstrates the effectiveness and robustness of DMPlug in handling nonlinear inverse problems.

caption: Table 1: (Nonlinear IP) Nonlinear deblurring with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01). (Bold: best, under: second best, green: performance increase, red: performance decrease)
description: This table presents a comparison of different methods for nonlinear image deblurring with Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01) on three datasets (CelebA, FFHQ, LSUN).  The metrics used for comparison include LPIPS (lower is better), PSNR (higher is better), and SSIM (higher is better). The table highlights the best and second-best performing methods for each metric and dataset, indicating performance improvements or decreases compared to the best-performing method.

caption: Table 1: (Nonlinear IP) Nonlinear deblurring with additive Gaussian noise (σ = 0.01). (Bold: best, under: second best, green: performance increase, red: performance decrease)
description: This table presents a comparison of different methods for nonlinear deblurring on three datasets (CelebA, FFHQ, and LSUN) with 0.01 additive Gaussian noise.  The metrics used for comparison are LPIPS (lower is better), PSNR (higher is better), and SSIM (higher is better).
